Once there was a small boy named Bayazid. He was very brilliant and devoted to his mother. One night he was studying by the side of the bed of his mother who was ill. Suddenly his mother woke up and told him to give her a glass of water. But he found that there was no water in the house.

Without any hesitation, Bayazid took the water pot and went out in search of water. It was a dark and cold night, and everyone was asleep. He walked a long distance to the nearest well. After collecting the water, he hurried back home. But when he reached home, he saw that his mother had fallen asleep again.

Bayazid did not want to wake her up. So, he stood beside her bed with the glass of water in his hand. He remained standing the whole night, waiting patiently for his mother to wake up. When his mother opened her eyes in the morning, she was surprised to see Bayazid standing with the glass of water. Tears came to her eyes, and she hugged her son with love.

Bayazid’s deep love and respect for his mother made him a great man later in life. His story continues to inspire children to honor and care for their pa
rents.

Ayat's Act of Kindness

One day Ayat, a school boy, was going to school on foot. While walking, he found a bundle of money on his way to school. He took the bundle of money and went to his class teacher."Ayat, what brings you here?" asked his teacher."Ma'am, I found this bundle of money on my way to school. I thought I should give it to you. Maybe someone lost it," replied Ayat.

His teacher was impressed by Ayat's honesty and kindness. She checked the bundle of money, found a small note with a name and phone number. She called the number and informed the person that Ayat had found the money. It turned out that the money belonged to an old woman who had saved it up for her grandson's treatment. She had lost it while going back from the bank.

The old woman was grateful when she got her money back. Then she thanked Ayat and his teacher for their honesty and kindness. She even invited Ayat to her house and gave him some home-cooked sweets as a token of gratitude. Ayat felt happy to see the smile on the old woman's face. He realized that helping others could bring joy and happiness to one's life. He decided to start a small charity program in his school to help the poor and needy.

Saying this, the woman started to cry which caught Arif off guard. He asked her whether she would like to drink some warm tea since the weather was cold. The offer brought a smile on the woman's wrinkled face. Near the dying river, there was an old tea store that Arif loved to visit. So he took the woman there for some tea. When he came to order their drinks at the counter, the owner told him that his companion told the strangest tales. No one knew where she came from and she had told thousand different stories to everyone who asked. With two cups of tea and newly learnt information, Arif returned to the old woman confused. A Lesson from the Wild

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Arpita/Apon living in Chattogram. Your fricnd Nafis who lives in the USA is very much concemed about the frequent road accidents in Bangladesh. Now, iwrite an email to your friend describing the causes and effects of road accidents in Bangladesh.

sub_questions.explanation:
Subject: Causes and Effects of Road Accidents in Bangladesh
Dear Nafis,
I hope you're doing well and everything is great on your end! I received your message and your concern about the frequent road accidents in Bangladesh. It’s definitely an issue that’s causing a lot of distress here, and I appreciate that you care about it.
The main causes of road accidents in Bangladesh are numerous, and many of them stem from both human errors and infrastructure-related issues. One of the primary causes is reckless driving, which includes speeding, overtaking dangerously, and not following traffic rules. There’s also the issue of poor road conditions in many areas—potholes, lack of proper signage, and narrow lanes make driving hazardous. The absence of proper pedestrian crossings and traffic lights in certain areas also adds to the problem.
Another factor is the increasing number of vehicles on the roads, which has led to congestion and drivers sometimes feeling impatient. Many drivers don’t respect traffic signals or signs, and there is a lack of proper enforcement of laws, which makes things worse. Poor visibility at night due to a lack of streetlights and the use of mobile phones while driving are also significant contributors.
The effects of these accidents are devastating. Loss of life is the most tragic impact, with thousands of families affected each year. Those who survive often suffer from serious injuries, many of which require long-term treatment or result in permanent disabilities. Apart from the human cost, the economic impact is also severe. The government and families bear the medical and rehabilitation expenses, and accidents often cause traffic jams that affect daily life and productivity.
It’s clear that urgent action is needed, from improving road infrastructure to better enforcement of traffic laws and educating the public about road safety. There’s also a need for stricter penalties for those who break the law and more investment in public transportation to reduce the number of cars on the road.
I hope this gives you a clearer picture of the situation. Let’s hope that over time, things will improve as more attention is given to this issue.
Take care, and keep in touch!
Warm regards, Arpita Chattogram, Bangladesh

Adiat: I’m fine, Maliha. But I’m really annoyed with this load shedding issue lately. It’s happening way too often.
Maliha: I feel the same. It disrupts everything—studying, cooking, and even sleeping. When the power goes out, everything comes to a standstill.
Adiat: Exactly! I was trying to complete an assignment last night, and the electricity went off for hours. I couldn’t finish my work on time.
Maliha: Yes, and it’s even worse for businesses. Shops lose customers, and those relying on machines or refrigeration suffer huge losses.
Adiat: True. Hospitals also face serious issues, especially during surgeries or when running life-support machines.
Maliha: You’re right. The authorities need to invest more in renewable energy, like solar and wind power, to tackle this issue.
Adiat: I agree. Also, fixing old power lines and proper maintenance could help reduce the problem.
Maliha: Absolutely! Until then, I guess we have no choice but to endure it. Still, we should raise awareness and ask for improvements.
Adiat: That’s a good idea, Maliha. Hopefully, things will get better soon.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Shipon/Shilpi. Nabil/Nabila is your friend. Both of you have some hobbies. Now, write a dialogue between you and your friend about your favourite hobby.

sub_questions.explanation:
Shilpi: Hey Nabila! How are you doing today?
Nabila: Hi Shilpi! I’m doing great. How about you?
Shilpi: I’m good too! I was just reading a new novel. You know how much I love reading books.
Nabila: Oh yes, I know! Reading is your favorite hobby, right?
Shilpi: Absolutely! I enjoy getting lost in stories. It helps me relax and also improves my imagination. What about you? What’s your favorite hobby?
Nabila: I love painting! Whenever I have free time, I take out my brushes and start creating something new.
Shilpi: That’s amazing! Painting needs a lot of creativity. What do you like to paint the most?
Nabila: I enjoy painting nature—like trees, rivers, and sunsets. It makes me feel peaceful. And I think painting is a great way to express emotions too.
Shilpi: That’s so beautiful. I’d love to see your paintings someday!
Nabila: And I’d love to share them with you! Maybe one day, you can read one of your favorite books while I paint the scene.
Shilpi: That sounds like a perfect day! Hobbies really make life more enjoyable, don’t they?
Nabila: Totally agree! They keep us happy and stress-free

questions.uddipok:
Suppose, you are Ahnaf/Ahona and your friend is Mohon/Mohona who is weak in English.

Now, write a dialogue between you and your friend about the ways of improving English.

sub_questions.explanation:
Ahnaf: Hey Mohon, I noticed you're having a tough time with English. What’s going on?

Mohon: Yeah, Ahnaf. I find it really hard to speak and understand English. I’m just not good at it.

Ahnaf: Don’t worry, Mohon. English can be tricky, but there are ways to improve. For starters, you could try reading books or watching movies in English. That helps you get used to the language.

Mohon: I tried reading, but I don’t always understand the words. What can I do?

Ahnaf: You can use a dictionary to look up unfamiliar words, or you can use apps on your phone to translate words quickly. Also, try reading aloud. It’ll help you with pronunciation.

Mohon: Okay, I’ll try that. But what about speaking? I’m too nervous to speak in English with others.

Ahnaf: That’s totally normal! But the more you practice, the more confident you’ll get. We can practice together. Just try speaking with me, and I’ll help you if you make any mistakes.

Mohon: Thanks, Ahnaf! I’m still a bit scared, but I’ll try to speak more. What else can I do?

Ahnaf: Another tip is to listen to English podcasts or songs. Pay attention to how they speak. You’ll pick up a lot of new words and improve your listening skills.

Mohon: That sounds fun! I’ll start listening to English songs and try speaking more.

Ahnaf: Great! And don’t stress about making mistakes. That’s how you learn. Just keep practicing, and you’ll improve for sure.

Mohon: Thanks, Ahnaf. I feel better now! I’ll definitely practice more.

Ahnaf: You’re welcome, Mohon. Keep at it, and you’ll do awesome!

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Nadim/Nadia, you have a friend named Fahim/Fahima who does not read newspaper. Now, write a dialogue between you and your friend about the importance of reading newspaper.

sub_questions.explanation:
Nadim : Hi, Fahim? How're you?

Fahim : Fine, thanks. What're you doing?

Nadim : I'm reading a newspaper. Will you take a page?

Fahim : No, thanks. I don't read newspaper.

Nadim : What! It's really surprising!

Fahim : Why? What's the importance of reading newspaper?

Nadim : Well. Newspaper is a collection of current affairs of the world. Without reading it, you're like a frog in a dark well. Do you know what are the burning issues of our country now? Or, what's going on in our neighbouring countries?

Fahim : Really not.

Nadim : But I know, because I read newspapers regularly. Newspapers can provide you with the news of the home and abroad. It's especially important for the students as it's the best medium of enriching our general knowledge. For this, it's called the storehouse of knowledge.

Fahim : You're right.

Nadim : Newspaper can make you introduce to the culture and customs of different countries of the world. You can know some such important information which are applicable to your practical life.

Fahim : You've opened my eyes. Now, I can feel the necessity of reading newspapers. Really, I'm detached from the current world. But I promise, I'll build up the
habit of reading newspaper from today. Thank you very much.

Nadim : You're most welcome.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Sostika/Anu, and your friend's name is Tanzima/Khalid. Now, write a dialogue between you and your friend about the severe impact of dengue fever.

sub_questions.explanation:
Sostika (Anu): Hey Tanzima, have you heard about the recent dengue outbreak in our area? It’s getting really serious!
Tanzima (Khalid): Yes, I’ve heard! My neighbor's cousin just got hospitalized with dengue fever. It's terrifying how quickly it spreads. What’s going on exactly?
Sostika (Anu): It’s caused by mosquitoes, right? They breed in stagnant water. Once a person is bitten, they can get a high fever, severe body aches, and even bleeding. It can be deadly if not treated in time.
Tanzima (Khalid): I read that hospitals are overwhelmed with patients, and the doctors are struggling to keep up. It’s so scary! Even young people are getting affected. I think it's spreading faster than last year.
Sostika (Anu): Yeah, it’s really alarming. The worst part is that there's no specific medicine for dengue. Treatment mainly focuses on relieving the symptoms, like reducing the fever and staying hydrated. It’s crucial to catch it early.
Tanzima (Khalid): That’s true. It’s affecting so many people in our community. I’ve seen people talking about how important it is to eliminate standing water around the house, like in old tires or containers, to prevent mosquito breeding.
Sostika (Anu): Exactly! Everyone should be extra careful about that. Mosquito nets and repellents can also help. The government and health organizations are doing their best, but we all need to take responsibility to stop the spread.
Tanzima (Khalid): We definitely need to spread awareness. People still don't take mosquito control seriously, but if we don’t, this will keep getting worse.
Sostika (Anu): True. We should tell everyone to clean up their surroundings, especially with the rains coming. Prevention is the key! Let’s spread the word in our neighborhood too.
Tanzima (Khalid): Yes, let’s do that! It’s up to all of us to stop dengue from spreading further. Stay safe, Anu!
Sostika (Anu): You too, Tanzima! Let’s stay vigilant and protect ourselves and others.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Idraq and your friend is Radit. Now, write a dialogue between you and your friend about dengue fever.

sub_questions.explanation:
Robin : Hi! How're you?

Fardin: I'm well; but worried about the dengue outbreak across the country.

Robin: Me either. What to do now? Shouldn't we take remedial measures?

Fardin: Of course.

Robin : I think the most effective way to prevent dengue outbreak is to prevent bites by the infected Aedes mosquitoes.

Fardin: I agree. We all should use mosquito repellents for that, shouldn't we?

Robin: Yes, we should. But we have to reduce the mosquito population first.

Fardin: Righṭ! We can do that by destroying their breeding places. Am I right?

Robin : You're absolutely right! For that, we should keep our dwelling places neat and clean. No stagnant water should be allowed in and around our,houses.

Fardin: Besides, we need to use mosquito nets while sleeping. By the way, what should the infected people do to be recovered?

Robin : It's true that there is no direct cure for dengue. However, doctors generally suggest the infected people to take rest and drink plenty of liquids. Some medicines like paracitamol, supplements are also prescribed.

Fardin: I see. Let's discuss the matter with our friends and start our work against the Aedes mosquitoes.

Robin: Let's go.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Karim/Karima, and your younger brother is Muhib. Write a dialogue between you and your brother about the merits and demerits of using mobile phone.

sub_questions.explanation:
Merits and demerits of using mobile phone
Amina : Hi, Asifa! Look, my parents have bought me a mobile phone.
Asifa : Wow! Now we can talk whenever we like. Isn't that wonderful?
Amina : Of course. Actually, the utility of mobile phones cannot be described in words.
Asifa : Right! We can keep in touch with friendș and family by a mobile phone.
Amina: Not only that. Internet browsing has become easier due to smart phones.
Asifa : Exactly! We can gather information and research many things helpful for our studies.
Amina : But it has some bad sides too.
Asifa : Yes. We often waste our valuable time by 'talking to our friends and relatives over'the phone for a long time or using social sites. Many people become addicted to virtual world through it.
Amina : It is also disturbing sometimes. There are some students and even some teachers who do not keep their mobile phones switched off during the class hours.
Asifa : Right! We all have experienced that. Moreover, using mobile phone isn't good for our body, too.
Amina : Really? How?
Asifa : Scientists have warned that excessive use of mobile phone can cause brain damage and hamper the mental growth of children.
Amina : Oh my God!
Asifa : So, we must be cautious while using it.
Amina : OK, we shouldn't talk over phone for long.
Asifa : Exactly. See you tomorrow! Bye!
Amina : Bye!

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Rasin. You have a friend Nobojit. He lives in a village. Now, write a dialogue between you and your friend on the merits and demerits of village life and city life.

sub_questions.explanation:
Ritu : Hello, Situ! Nice to see you here. How are you?
Situ : I'm fine, thanks. What about you?
Ritu : I'm ok. I think it would be better if you got yourself admitted into a college in the city as I did.
Situ : I don't think so, Ritu. Actually, I don't like cities.
Ritu : Why? What're the things of city life you dislike?
Situ : I think, life in the city is very artificial. People lead a very busy life there. They get up in the morning hearing the noises of motor vehicles, machines and factories.
Ritu : You're right. But there are many modern facilities that you can have only in cities. Good educational institutes, hospitals and clinics are mainly available in the city. Again, there are many spots for recreations.
Situ: : That's true. But I think life in the village is far better than that of the town. Village life is quite natural. People lead a very simple life. They wake up from sleep hearing the chirping of the birds and can breathe in fresh air: Do you have fresh fish in the town
Ritu : - Actually, fishes are available there, but not fresh.
Situ : But fresh food, fishes, vegetables, fruits etc. are available in the village, Moreover, village life is pollution free.
Ritu : You're right. But village life is not without its disadvantages. Disease, hunger, malnutrition and poverty are common in the life of the villagers. Also, jobs are not available here.
Situ : Hmm. Actually, both lives have their advantages and disadvantages. I think a balanced development can remove the gap between these two types of life.
Ritu : Yes. I agree with you. See you later.
Situ : Ok, bye. Take a good care of yourself.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Shakir/Shakira and your friend is Talha/Tania.. Your friend does not get up early in the morning. For this reason he/she faces many problems. Now, write a dialogue between you and your friend about the importance of early rising.

sub_questions.explanation:
Shakir: Hey Talha! You look really tired today. What’s up?
Talha: Ugh, I didn’t sleep well. I went to bed late and couldn’t get up early in the morning.
Shakir: That’s not good, man. You’ve been struggling with waking up late for a while now, haven’t you?
Talha: Yeah, and it’s causing so many problems. I miss breakfast, get late for school, and feel lazy all day.
Shakir: That’s exactly why early rising is important! It gives you a fresh start and enough time to plan your day properly.
Talha: I know, but I just can't seem to leave my bed in the morning!
Shakir: Try going to bed earlier. Trust me, waking up early makes you feel more energetic and focused. Plus, you can enjoy the peaceful morning atmosphere.
Talha: Hmm, that actually sounds nice. Do you wake up early every day?
Shakir: I try to. I go for a short walk, enjoy the fresh air, and it really helps me concentrate better in class.
Talha: Alright, I’ll give it a try. Maybe I’ll set an alarm for 6 AM tomorrow!
Shakir: That’s the spirit! Start with small steps. You’ll notice the change soon.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are David and.Max is your friend. People of all walks of life are suffering terribly from frequent electricity failure. Now, write a dialogue between you and your friend about the painful effect of it.

sub_questions.explanation:
David: Hi Max, have you noticed how frequent the electricity failures have become lately? It’s getting unbearable!
Max: Absolutely, David. It’s so frustrating, especially in the evenings when I’m trying to study or do something important.
David: I know, right? For me, it’s the worst during the nights. It’s impossible to sleep with all the heat and no fans running.
Max: Not to mention, businesses are suffering too. Shops can’t keep their refrigerators running, and factories face disruptions. It’s affecting the economy.
David: Exactly. Even in hospitals, I’ve heard there’s trouble maintaining critical operations. The constant power cuts are making life difficult for everyone.
Max: And students like us are suffering too. Imagine having exams but no electricity to prepare! It’s such a setback.
David: True. It feels like no one is addressing the issue seriously. They should invest more in alternative energy sources or at least improve the power grid.
Max: Agreed. Solar energy and other renewables could help reduce this dependency. But it takes planning and commitment.
David: Yes, and until then, we need better schedules for power cuts so people can plan their days. Let’s hope for a better solution soon.
Max: I hope so too, David. This situation really needs urgent attention from the authorities.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Tanveer/Tanisa. You have a friend named Habib/Habiba who is fond of trees and nature. Now; write a dialogue between you and your friend about the importance of tree plantation.

sub_questions.explanation:
Tanveer : Hi, Habib! Where're you going?

Habib : I'm going to attend the tree plantation programme.
Tanveer : Really! I must appreciate you. You might know how much trees are important for us.
Habib : Of course, they supply the fuel of our life, that is, oxygen.
Tanveer :. Exactly! You know, they also absorb carbon dioxide.
Habib : Right! They are the main sources of food.
Tanveer: Tree keeps our ecological balance, protects river erosion, and provides sheds to our beasts and birds.
Habib : They give us shade and what is more important is that they prevent natural calamities.
Tanveer : Right and in a word, tree plantation is a must for our survival.
Habib : Definitely! Again, Bangladesh is one of the worst sufferers of climate change. So, we have no other way but planting more and more trees.

Tanveer : I agree with you.
Habib : Moreover, for furniture, fuel, medicine, etc., we depend on trees.
Tanveer : Exactly. Let's go to the programme!
Habib : Let's go!

questions.uddipok: Imagine, you are Sabuj and Sagor is your friend. Your friend is addicted to smoking. Now, write a dialogue between you and your friend about the bad effects of smoking.

sub_questions.explanation:
Sabuj: Hey Sagor, I’ve noticed you’ve been smoking a lot lately. Don’t you think it’s affecting your health?
Sagor: I know, Sabuj, but it helps me relax. Everyone smokes, so it’s not a big deal.
Sabuj: I get that it feels calming, but have you considered how dangerous it is? Smoking can lead to serious problems like lung cancer, heart disease, and even strokes.
Sagor: Yeah, I’ve heard that, but it feels hard to quit. I’ve tried, but it’s tough.
Sabuj: I understand it’s hard, but think about your future. You’re still young—your lungs and heart are strong now, but smoking can damage them permanently over time. It shortens your life, too.
Sagor: I know it’s bad, but I can’t seem to stop. What do you suggest I do?
Sabuj: Maybe start by cutting down slowly. Try to replace cigarettes with healthier habits, like exercise or chewing gum. You could also talk to a doctor—they can help you with a plan to quit.
Sagor: I guess it’s worth a try. Thanks, Sabuj. I’ll think about it seriously.
Sabuj: I’m here to support you, Sagor. You’ve got this!

questions.uddipok: Suppose, your are Shamim/Shamima. Your friend is Rahim/Rahima. You want to do something good for the people of your locality after your SSC Examination. Now, write a dialogue between you and your friend about your plan that you are going to materialize after the SSC Examination

sub_questions.explanation:
Minhaj : Hello, Rizwan! How're you?

Rizwan : Fine by the grace of Almighty Allah. And you?

Minhaj : I'm also fine. What're you going to do after the SSC Exam, Rizwan?

Rizwan : After the SSC Exam, I want to go to Chattogram. What about you?

Minhaj : Well, I've a plan after the SSC Examination.

Rizwan : What's your plan after the exam? May I know?

Minhaj : Of course, Why not! After the exam I'll get admitted to a coaching centre.

Rizwan : That's good. Which coaching will you choose?

Minhaj : Actually, I'll do computer coaching because I've a dream to be a software developer.

Rizwan : But I want to finish my honours in English because I like multinational jobs.

Minhaj : Your. plan is also nice, but 'we've to study a lot to achieve our goals and have to be admitted to a reputed college.

Rizwan : As there are many students in country in comparison to educational institutions, it'll be tough to get through.

Minhaj : That's true. But if we've confidence, we can ensure our position.

Rizwan : : Sure. When are you going to be admitted?

Minhaj : Next week.

Rizwan. : I want to go with you too.

Minhaj : Why not! Keep in touch. See you next week.

Rizwan : Ok, bye.

questions.uddipok: Climate change increases the frequency, severity and unpredictability of cyclones; floods and other extreme weather events seriously affecting Bangladesh. Now, write a dialogue bètween you and your friend about the environmental hazards and threatening effect of climate change in the life of people of Bangladesh.

sub_questions.explanation:
About the environmental hazards and threatning effect of climate change in Bangladeshi people's life.
Asha : Tina, have you noticed how unpredictable the pattern of weather has become lately? It's been hitting our coastal areas really hard.
Tina : Absolutely. Just last week, another cyclone warning was issued. It's heart-breaking to think about the families living in those vulnerable areas.
Asha : Yes, the frequency and intensity of these cyclones are rising due to climate change. Many people have lost their homes and livelihoods because of the repeated flooding.
Tina : And it's not just the coastal areas. Even here in the cities, we've seen an increase in extreme heatwaves. It's making life unbearable, especially for those without adequate shelter or access to cooling.
Asha : That's true. The rising temperatures are causing severe health issues too. The elderly and children are the most affected by heatrelated illnesses.
Tina : And let's not forget about agriculture. The unpredictable rainfall patterns are devastating for farmers. Crops are getting damaged, and food security is becoming a major concern.

Asha : I believe we need to focus on both mitigation and adaptation strategies. People need to understand the urgency of the situation and how they can contribute to slowing down climate change. Small changes in our daily lives, like reducing waste and conserving energy, can help us in great deal.
Tina :. Yes, and supporting renewable energy projects can also help.
Asha : I agree. Actually it's a collective effort. The government, organizations, and èvery individual need to come together to combat this crisis. After all, it's about securing a sustainable future for all of us.
Tina : Exactly. I also think so. I have to go now, bye.
Asha: See you later, bye.

questions.uddipok: We are facing natural calamity this year worsely. Though nature goes its own way, we are mostly responsible for the best use of nature. Now, write a dialogue between you and your friend, Ratul on our responsibility to save the nature.

sub_questions.explanation:
Tamim : Hey Ratul, have you noticed how we're facing more severe natural calamities this year?
Ratul: Yeah, it's really alarming. The floods,storms, and heatwaves are getting worse. It's like nature is fighting back.
Tamim : Absolutely. While nature has its own course, we are mostly for not using it wisely. We need to take the responsibility to save it.
Ratul: Right. We can't just sit back and let things get worse. So, what do you think we should do to help save nature?
Tamim : For starters, we need to reduce our carbon emission. Simple things like using public transport, reducing waste, and conserving energy can make a big difference.
Ratul: Hmm... that makes sense. Also, promoting reforestation is crucial. Trees are essential for maintaining ecological balance.
Tamim : Exactly. We should also be mindful of water usage. With the growing water crisis, conserving water is essential.
Ratul :True. Every drop counts! And raising awareness is equally important.Educating people about the impact of their actions on the environment can lead to more responsible behavior.
Tamim: Absolutely. We can't ignore this anymore. Every small action leads towards a bigger change.
Ratul :Let's start with our community.
Tamim: Alright. Together, we can make a bigdifference. Let's do our part toprotect our planet.
Ratul : Let's do it!

questions.uddipok:
Suppose, you are Rohan/Raiyana reading in class ten. You along with your classmates want to make a garden in front of your school. So, you need to talk to the headmaster.
Now, write a dialogue between you and the headmaster about making a garden.

sub_questions.explanation:
Raiana : May I come in, sir?
Headmaster : Yes, please come in. Tell me, what can I do for you?
Raiana :  Sir, we would like to make a small garden in front of our school. There is a piece of land in front of our campus where the local cowboys graze their cattle. We want to use the land for making a small garden.
Headmaster : Well, that's a good idea. Who is going to execute the plan?
Raiana : We, the students of class ten, would execute the plan. Our honourable class teacher, Mrs Morshed gave her consent to coordinate the project.
Headmaster : Great! But you know, a garden needs to be taken care of. Are you ready to take the trouble? Besides, you cannot hamper your studies.
Raiana : Yes, sir. We have it in our mind. We'll take care of the garden properly. Again, when we become busy with studies, the students of class nine will take part in gardening. We will do it by turns.
Headmaster : I like your plan. Ok, I give you the permission. But you've to write an application to me for that.
Raiana : Sure, sir. We'll submit an application, tomorrow.
Headmaster : May Allah bless you.
Raiana : Thanks you, sir.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Tabib and your friend is Rohan. Now, write a dialogue between you and your friend about how to develop leàdership qualities.

sub_questions.explanation:
Tabib : Hi Rohan, I've been thinking about how to improve my leadership skills. Any ideas?
Rohan : Definitely, Tabib. You can start with developing good communication skills. Being able to convey your thoughts, clearly and listen to others is the key.
Tabib : That makes sense. What else?
Rohan : Taking on responsibilities is important too. You can start the practice at home. Besides, try to be a reliable volunteer for projects or tasks that challenge you. It helps build confidence and experience.
Tabib : So, stepping out of my comfort zone is crucial. Got it. What about decisionmaking?
Rohan : Yes, making decisions and taking ownership is vital. It shows you're willing to lead and handle the consequences.
Tabib : How about teamwork?
Rohan : Absolutely. Working well with others and understanding team dynamics is essential. A good leader supports and motivates his/her team.
Tabib : I see. Any tips on handling conflicts?
Rohan : Stay calm and objective. Focus on resolving the issue, not on 'who's right or wrong'. Effective conflict resolution can earn you respect.
Tabib : These are great points, Rohan. Anything else?
Rohan : Always keep learning. Read books, attend workshops, and seek feedback. Continuous improvement is the mark of a true leader.
Tabib : Thanks, Rohan! I feel more confident about developing my leadership skills now.
Rohan : Anytime, Tabib. Just remember, leadership is a journey, not a destination.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Ebad and your friend is Rifa. Now, write a dialogue between you and your friend about tree plantation

sub_questions.explanation:
Ebad : Hi Rifa, how are you?
Rifa : I'm good, Ebad! How about you?
Ebad : I'm doing great, thanks! You know, I was reading about the importance of tree plantation recently. It really made me think about how much we depend on trees for our environment.
Rifa : Oh, that’s interesting! What exactly did you read about? I’ve heard tree plantation is important, but I don’t know much about it.
Ebad : Well, trees help in many ways. They absorb carbon dioxide, give us oxygen, prevent soil erosion, and even provide shade. Planting more trees can help fight climate change and make our surroundings healthier.
Rifa : That’s true. I’ve also noticed how many trees have been cut down in our area for construction. The environment is getting worse because of that.
Ebad : Yes, exactly. That’s why tree plantation is so important. It’s not just about planting trees, but also about raising awareness and protecting the ones we already have. We could start a small tree plantation drive in our neighborhood. What do you think?
Rifa : I love the idea! We can plant trees around schools, parks, and even along roadsides. Maybe we could ask others to join us, too.
Ebad : Absolutely! If we get more people involved, it will make a bigger impact. We could also share information about how to take care of the plants after they are planted, so they grow strong.
Rifa : That’s a great plan! Let’s get started soon. I’m sure it will make a difference in our community.
Ebad : Yes, it will. Together, we can help make our environment greener and cleaner!
Rifa : I’m excited! Let’s begin planning right away!
Ebad : Alright, I’ll gather some information and we can meet tomorrow to discuss it further. Thanks for being so enthusiastic, Rifa!
Rifa : Of course, Ebad! I’m happy to help. See you tomorrow!

questions.uddipok:
Suppose you are Nabil/Nabila. You have a friend called Nabeen/Nabeena. Both of you are very interested in different types of games and sports.
Now, write a dialogue between you and your friend emphasizing the importance of games and sports in our life.

sub_questions.explanation:
Nabeen/Nabeena ：Hi Nabil/Nabila, where are you heading to?
Nabil/Nabila : Hi, I'm on my way to the sports club.
Nabeen/Nabeena : What do you do there?
Nabil/Nabila : Well, I practise badminton there.
Nabeen/Nabeena : That's interesting!Do you go there often?
Nabil/Nabila : Yes, almost every day. It keeps my body and mind fit. Do you participate in any sports, Nabeen/Nabeena?
Nabeen/Nabeena : Yes, I do.
Nabil/Nabila : Which sports are you interested in?
Nabeen/Nabeena : I usually play cricket and football to keep my body fit and healthy.
Nabil/Nabila : I think, games are essential for good health.
Nabeen/Nabeena : You're right, Nabil/Nabila. Games are essential for a healthy body.
Nabil/Nabila : Some people don't like physical activities. They don't realize the importance of games.
Nabeen/Nabeena : But such people always suffer from one or the other ailment.
Nabil/Nabila : You're absolutely right.
Nabeen/Nabeena : I personally think that games should be made compulsory for the students.
Nabil/Nabila : I agree with you. Games will keep the students healthy and teach them discipline.
Nabeen/Nabeena : Discipline is very essential for the progress of an individual as well as the nation as a whole.
Nabil/Nabila : Games also teach us the spirit of sportsmanship while developing the quality of leadership among the students.
Nabeen/Nabeena : 'Health is wealth', is an old saying. Therefore, to maintain our health we must play games.
Nabil/Nabila : Yes. You're right. Well, I've to go now. We should meet up again, may be next week.
Nabeen/Nabeena : Sure! See you then.
Nabil/Nabila : Bye, bye.
Nabeen/Nabeena : good bye.
